docs.abstract: The good, the bad and the ugly effects of media access on children.
docs.lead_paragraph: Young Americans from the ages of 8 to 18 spend more than seven and a half hours a day on average using a smart phone, computer, television or other electronic device. On top of that, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation study released last week detailing these habits, many children are electronic multitaskers -- surfing the Web, for example, while listening to music or watching TV.
docs.snippet: The good, the bad and the ugly effects of media access on children.

headline.main: Medical Marijuana Supporters Wonder if Time Has Come

docs.abstract: Medical marijuana is now legal in New Jersey. Its supporters in New York wonder if their time has come.
docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey added a new herb to its state garden last Tuesday when Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed the New Jersey Compassionate Use Medical Marijuana Act on his last day in office.
docs.snippet: Medical marijuana is now legal in New Jersey. Its supporters in New York wonder if their time has come.

headline.main: Using Soccer to Supplant Kerosene Use?

docs.abstract: A group of Harvard students are hoping that a soccer ball that generates and stores electricity during normal play will help offset the use of kerosene in the developing world.
docs.lead_paragraph: In many developing countries, heavy reliance on kerosene lamps has led to myriad health problems. The World Bank, for example, estimates that breathing the fumes created from burning kerosene indoors equals the harmful effects of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day.
docs.snippet: A group of Harvard students are hoping that a soccer ball that generates and stores electricity during normal play will help offset the use of kerosene in the developing world.

headline.print_headline: Behavior: TV Viewing Habits Tied to Life Expectancy
headline.seo: Study Ties TV Viewing Habits to Life Expectancy
headline.main: Behavior: Too Much Sitting Shortens Lives, Study Suggests

docs.lead_paragraph: Research in Australia showed that each daily hour of television viewing was associated with an 11 percent rise in mortality.
docs.snippet: Research in Australia showed that each daily hour of television viewing was associated with an 11 percent rise in mortality.
